Title: Cross product: matrix transformation identity
Content: How can one prove the following identity of the cross product? $$(M a)\times (M b)=\det(M) (M^{\rm T})^{-1}(a\times b)$$ $a$ and $b$ are 3-vectors, and $M$ is an invertible real $3 \times 3$ matrix.
AcceptedAnswer:
Recall that $u\times v$ is the only vector $w\in\mathbb{R}^3$ that satisfies 
$$\forall\, x\in\mathbb{R}^3,\quad \det(u,v,x)=\langle w,x\rangle$$
So, we have
$$\eqalign{\det(M)\langle a\times b,x\rangle&=
\det(M)\det(a,b,x)\cr&=\det(Ma,Mb,Mx)\cr
&=\langle Ma\times Mb,Mx\rangle\cr
&=\langle M^T(Ma\times Mb),x\rangle\cr
}
$$
Thus
$$\forall\, x\in\mathbb{R}^3,\quad \langle\det(M)( a\times b),x\rangle=\langle M^T(Ma\times Mb),x\rangle$$
It follows that $\det(M)( a\times b)=M^T(Ma\times Mb)$ or equivalently, for an invertible matrix $M$, 
$$\det(M)(M^T)^{-1}( a\times b)= Ma\times Mb $$ Remark. The most general formula is 
$${\rm Co}(M)( a\times b)= Ma\times Mb$$
where ${\rm Co}(M)$ is the matrix of cofactors of $M$. Here we do not need $M$ to be invertible. This follows from the proved formula by continuity.
